comment: Nice rye, much better than the double rye.  Very easy drinker.

Sometimes I feel terrible reviewing whiskey here, because I read everyone else's opinion and hate to be the contrarian. But alas I must, though in all fairness I should disclose that I do not generally like rye whiskies. Here's a related set of questions: do you like pickles? How about dill? Or vinegar? Oh and garlic? If you answered no to any of these questions, WALK AWAY FROM THIS BOTTLE! Do not pass go, do not collect $200! As improbable as this sounds, the nose has dominant aromas of dill and vinegar, with a touch of pickles (yeah I know, sounds crazy). The palate is lumber, like walking through a Loews lumber yard on a humid summer day, and the finish is long, which is either a good or bad thing depending on your opinion about carpentry. I actually don't dislike this whiskey. I'm just confused by it.

Just tried this for the first time. Really a great sip. Wonderful, smooth, molasses front end. Long, slow, warm, peppery finish. The start and finish almost give the illusion of two separate drinks. I'll be adding this to the collection soon.
Smells something like an oaky Pinot noir. Smooth, easy to drink.

Rich and spicy, with good tobacco and leather, light 
cinnamon and cream hints

Currently, my favorite whiskey, although I tried not to like it since Heidi was introduced to it by Nick. Big, bold and spicy. Hits you in the back of the throat and then lingers. Guess I'm a rye drinker.
Vibrant  and lingering spice yet smooth  with just enough sweetness.  Aftertaste offers interesting complexity. Hot but not overwhelming and goes down easily.

N: dill pickle, apple
T: smooth very little bite, pickle, rye, dry finish,
Really a 4.5 but a nice heated rye whiskey.
Burnt sugar, vanilla, and overall hot.
Hell of a whiskey. The meeting of sweetness, Spice and robustness. Try it and it will never fail you. Butterscotch, hints of banana, vanilla. All presented in a complex, full and delicate body.

Nose- slightly astringent, crushed black pepper, cayenne, molasses, and anise
Body- molasses, anise, black pepper and mint
Finish- long and warm with a sweet straw like flavor
Smells like hair spray but tastes good.
Probably the best rye I've tried to date. Smooth, for a rye, and great flavor.
Tried it in DC. Loved it. If you see it, get some!! Had it again in Annapolis at Dry 85. Excellent!!
Sweet on the front, spicy on the back. Good rye, probably would make a solid Manhattan. Would be 5 stars if it was just a touch sweeter / smoother.
Vanilla with mint to start, then a nice warm bath of spice on the palate mostly cinnamin. Long full finish. Great finish as flavors linger on the back of your tounge.
Mulling spices on nose, spicy finish, fruity in palate, bolder than the double, slightly more complex

This is my go to Rye blend. Excellent as a sipper, I could drink this all night if it wasn't $50-$60/bottle. Makes an Old Fashioned or Manhattan just a bit more special. I prefer it with a little ice. Tons of flavor - sweet, vanilla, a little peppery spice.
This is an excellent rye. Perfect for sipping straight or using in a Manhattan.
Exceedingly nice rye for the money successfully marrying the vibrancy of a young rye with the richness of an old.  Lots of mint spice with a robust lingering rye finish.  Outstanding!
I like how this lingers. It doesn't just kick ya and leave. It stays around and plays and dances on your tongue.

The grand-daddy of widely available American straight ryes, without a doubt. A blend of 6- and 16-year-old straight ryes, Rendezvous mixes the liveliness of a good, young rye mixed with some of the mellow elegance of a good older rye. At first there are a lot of flavours I associate with LDI rye: dill, pickle, menthol, something "gin-like". But then those mellow and it really starts to come together into something softer, sweeter. Caramel, ginger, vanilla, watermelon. Cinnamon, candy corn, bubble gum, caraway, brown sugar, custard. Creme brulee and tropical fruits. A hint of pencil shavings. Taste is, considering its two high-rye mashbills, surprisingly soft, creamy, and sweet.
Very smooth but with enough spice from the rye to make it linger on the palate so you don't soon forget about it. This stands out as one of the best High West products.
Super spicy, lots of rye flavor. Smells of fruitcake.
6/9/15 at Hops & Hominy SF. Neat at first, then two ice cubes. Smooth, balanced. An excellent rye.
Younger rye, older rye, singing in perfect harmonye. Tasted at WhiskyFest New York 2015
Good, complex rye. Lots of floral flavors in the background like the Double Rye, but the Rendezvous Rye has vanilla and burnt sugars up front.

Nose - Hits you with the typical rye notes of rye bread, mint, dill. Then you get vanilla, caramel, a very buttery creme brulee, then something oddly refreshing, like a bosc pear.
Taste - Attacks your tongue with a spicy cinnamon. A hint of mint and cocoa nibs make their presence along with the fruity pear from the nose, followed by a very buttery vanilla ice cream.
Finish - Cinnamon spice lingers, like red hots or a buttery atomic fireball, but without the artificial sweet but more of the vanilla butter / creme brulee.
89/100

Simply brilliant rye.  Was skeptical of sourced whiskies but HW has changed my perspective. Such an amazing dance of mellowed, matured, woody, and carmel-ly (peaches?!) sweet along with the slightly subdued spicy backbone of a younger rye. Although I think EH Taylor rye is amazing, I'd rather have a Rendezvous with High West  given the chance.

Living in Salt Lake City damn do I feel lucky to have this so close to me and always available. This is my all time favorite whiskey. I know people piss and moan about it being sourced but I challenge you to find a better tasting rye.
(1/23/16) Tried both standard Rendezvous Rye and Rendezvous Rye finished for 2+ years in a bourbon barrel.
One of the best ryes I've ever had. Period.
Pretty sure I have this one too – probably will be my third bottle
These guys make the most drinkable whiskey. Awesome session rye

Bottle opened on 21st wedding anniversary for a celebratory dram.
Nose: mint, molasses, vanilla.
Palate: low viscosity, crisp clean mouthfeel (the young rye?) but at the same time a deeper spicy complexity coming through. Sweet, bright, fruity tones only just breaking through - almost out of reach. Woody, vanilla, mint, aniseed, light tobacco deeper complexity also there. Nicely balanced. Long finish with lingering spiciness, light heat and subtle sweetness. Great finish! 
Some water just toned everything down but didn't really open up anything new.
Neat, slowly savoured and sipped is the way to go with this one. One for the top shelf in my view.

[07.19.2016] My 100th review after the United Airlines (no)flight from hell. Solid but nothing special. Heat and barrel with typical rye. Not impressed. 

This is sweet and cherry sour like pricey cough syrup. Nose is a lot of barrel that mixes with vanilla, floral spice (is that a real thing???) and a fair bit of heat after a few stouts. Good, but not repeatable. A table of 4 is unanimous.
Had with Lisa Halprin and husband Art during Aug 2016 visit (hotel bar, near Global Market). Okay. Nothing special.

Not sure why this gets the score it does but the rye is on point. Smooth with complexity and great spice flavor. No burn here as it strolls down your palate leaving a trail of vanilla and spice. God lordy lord this is goog. 92/100 in my book
Very drinkable, enjoyable Rye. Nice spicy finish brings out all the standard rye offerings. Could definitely be a good standard rye for the Bourbon enthusiast.
I don't drink a lot of Rye's, but this is a damned good one.
Very mild nose. Nice rye bite
Good but Double Rye is better for 1/2 the price
Succotash, D.C. SCMR 1/2017. Nice rye.  Not worth the extra price.
Even more enjoyable than double rye
Sweet mint nose. Leather, sweetness & mint flavor with hints of chocolate. Mild sweet mint finish. Batch # 14IO8A bottle #1. Thanks JT.
Grassy with unwelcome surprise of dill on the nose, and splintering fresh oak spice on the palate. Driftwood finish. Unfortunately one of the worst whiskeys I have ever tasted.
This is the best standard release High West has to offer and it's fantastic!!! If I were forced to pick one whiskey for the rest of my days, this would be it!

Batch No. 16D15. Soft baking spices, molasses cookies, hints spearmint and trail mix, complex and layered, rich and smooth, reminiscent of aged rum. Makes a lovely Old Fashioned (muddle sugar cube with Peychaud barrel aged bitters, add 1/4tsp. Clement Creole Shrub, 2oz. rye, ice, luxardo cherry garnish). I'm not certain it's worth the price over Rittenhouse BIB, but I will certainly enjoy this bottle. Contains 6yo (95% rye mashbill) LDI/MGP rye vatted with 16yo (80% rye mashbill) Barton rye.
Easy, sweeter and not too spicy for a rye.  Killer.

2017-09-01
At Kenton's in N.O.
Nice flavor.  Smooth.
Pepper, caramel on the very end of the palate.
cloves are lightly there. but provide some spice. good caramel softness
1/10/2018 Frugal MacDoogal’s, $63, a very nice rye! I’d buy this one again!

46% abv
non chill-filtered
Blend and mashbill (via their website):  A blend of older Straight Rye whiskeys ranging in age from 4 to 7 years.
Straight Rye whiskeys: 
95% rye, 5% barley malt from MGP
80% rye, 20% malted rye from High West Distillery

Nose: caramel, honey and vanilla greet you, followed by well-rounded rye spiciness along with hints of dill, dark fruit and nutmeg.


Taste: deep and complex, with caramel and vanilla initially but as it develops, you get oakiness, dill, zesty rye spice, light tobacco in the background.


Finish: long and spicy, with the oak char becoming more assertive with a hint of maple and brown sugar. 


Value: at $45-65 USD, this one is worth it.


Final thoughts/Score: High West is doing some amazing blends, and this one is no exception. It's a complex, versatile and easy going sipper I recommend to anyone getting into rye, especially if you are a bourbon-first drinker, as the bourbon notes of this blend really shine, coming likely from the older rye. Great neat, can stand up to ice (if that is your thing) and would work well in a cocktail. All this said, when originally released it was blended 16 yo rye from Barton, but has been replaced by their in-house distillate. This earlier blend must have been a real treat, so if you can find an older bottle (earlier that 2017) it's a must buy!

4/5: highly recommend buying a bottle.

Malt Musing: “Happiness is having a rare steak, a bottle of whisky, and a dog to eat the rare steak.” - Johnny Carson
Great everyday rye, great for cocktails too

As soon as I sipped this rye, it instantly vaulted into first place among all of the ryes I've tried, which admittedly is a much smaller number than scotches or bourbons.  The blend of two differently aged whiskies has produced a complex set of aromas, but all of them delightful:  cappuccino, caramel, rye spice, pineapple, and butterscotch.  Then even more flavors pop up in the palate:  creamy oatmeal, dill, vanilla, and citrus notes.  The rye spice is quite strong in all three phases, but manifests most strongly after the swallow, when it combines with yeasty bread flavors, mint, and orange.  At $60-70, this is not cheap, but it's much richer and more complex than its more affordable cousins.

Was in the mood for a Rye today, and this was the first Rye I grabbed. I've heard good things about it, and I have to say, they are true. The nose starts with an intense smell of mint-chocolate sweets, some cloves and a very interesting layer of aloe vera. Fresh and spicy, unlike any other Rye I had before. I don't get any of that chocolate in the taste, but there is still a lot of that fresh and spicy mint, a nice satisfying base layer of roasted brown sugar, some anise and other rye spices and quite a bit of heat. Not very sweet, but still enjoyable. The finish is medium long and rather on the spicy side, again typical for Rye in my expierence. It is a bit more expensive than for example Bulleit Rye, but it's worth the extra money. I'm curious how the Double Rye will compare to this.
Good spice, though not especially spicy for a rye. Great flavor. Black pepper notes are welcome. The sweetness is a mature sweet - think cocoa vs candy. Finishes long and smooth.

I don't care for. Too much clove, spicy flavor. 
Rating: 2.5
Dill, caramel, banana, and a hint of anise on the nose.  Taste is sweet, spicy, and just a bit savory.  A bit too much rye for my liking.  Finish is long, grainy, sweet, and a bit oaky.
sample/still almost worthy of 4 *s.  I do prefer Double Rye over this as I feel it stands out from the rye pack in a clear way.
Very smooth rye with light peppery and spice notes. Would be a good everyday sipper!

I now see what all the fuss is about! This is an absolute knock out of a rye! At the $55-$60 range it's hard to beat. Upon entry you are hit with subtle dill, baking spices, vanilla and brown sugar. The mid palatte features a clove swell that reminds you you are indeed drinking a rye. Finally the long finish features oak, caramel, clove, dill and more baking spices. Incredibly smooth. Wonderful stuff. Strong recommendation! Either this or Pikesville in this price range for a Rye. 4.5/5
I can definitely taste a little more age than the average rye. Complex flavors, but not too intense. Notes of hay, rye, anise, molasses, wood, darker fruits and a hint of mint

Smooth， relaxing， and zen feel. 
A  perfect bottle After hard day of work. 
Play a little jazz along with your drink. 
89/100

Some fruity notes on the nose. Excellent mouth feel. Palette starts of sweet light brown sugar notes quickly shifting to enjoyable amount of warm spices with some black pepper notes. Finish is mostly quick with a pleasant warmth.
Rich, hot but on the good side of it (although might get old). straightforward. fruity.
Extremely smooth. Bartender gave us a free sample and it was amazing. He had it at $22 per shot which was a little overpriced for the bottle cost.
Soft, little spice and mint. I hate eyes but I dig this.

Cotton candy and RC Cola on the nose.

Straight different on the taste like caramel and vanilla, maybe some apple.
Very spicy compared to other ryes I had.
Boring execution on a standard rye.  Not at all worth the price.

floral, polleny sweetness on the nose. floral sweetness rather than candy sweetness. I like it. sweet with a lightly spicy finish. surprised by the flavor profile for a rye. apples, jam, walk in the flower garden. lovely.

I assume most on here are familiar with Rendevous Rye, but for those that are not, it is High West’s higher end, older rye (they also make a less expensive Double Rye, amongst other things). It’s sourced juice from MGP and Barton, but High West is very open about this and is a leader in transparency about its production process.

Age: A blend of older straight rye whiskeys ranging in age from 5 to 19 years.

Mashbill: 95% rye, 5% barley malt from MGP; 53% rye, 37% corn, 10% from Barton Distillery; and 80% rye, 10% corn, 10% barley malt from Barton Distillery.

Abv: 46%

Price: $53.99 at Total Wine in Houston, Texas

Setting: Neat in a Glencairn, with a fat basset hound dozing next to me.

Nose: Big aromas of dill pickles and rye, with some secondary notes of cinnamon, vanilla, and brown sugar if you search for them. (21/25 points)

Taste: Very consistent with the nose. Dill pickles and rye. (44/50 points)

Finish: A medium length finish of rye spice and oak with a pleasant alcohol burn. I also get a flavor I’ll call mint, although that may not be the best descriptor. (21/25) points)

Conclusion: If one enjoys pickles (as I do), then this is a highly enjoyable whiskey. If one doesn’t, then this probably tastes pretty vile. As such, I’d only recommend this to people who fit into the former category. Regardless, this is a well-made whiskey. All three components are solid, and it is just enjoyable to drink. It is fairly expensive for an American whiskey, so I won’t be in a hurry to replace my existing bottle when I finish it, but I am glad I purchased this bottle.

86/100
MGPI product, well mixed by HW, but more expensive than it should be. Grassy and spicy, sweet grain, rich and warm. Sipping or cocktails, can't go wrong.

2014 batch. Smells soapy, robust. Strong floral notes, some dill, brown sugar. Classic rye profile but maybe more intense. Ends with slight wood notes, pecan shells, and Sprite. If you like rye, this is a good one
big bold flavors, not as spicy or as much rye flavors as the double rye but still very good
brown sugar and apple notes accented with rye spiciness to tone down the sweetness, smooth with great long finish
Tasted with Jeffrey. He loves it. A little burny, but not bad.
Nose is minty with a bit of cinnamon. The finish is long, and the flavors work well together. Its a very satisfying rye that probably makes bomb cocktails.
For the price this is the perfect rye. Spicy, fruity, vanilla, great barrel. Love love love this stuff.
Smooth, balanced, with a long finish

Pickling spices, sawdust and cinnamon on the nose. Thick mouthfeel with light pickling spices, cola and oak in the flavor profile.  Lightly sweet, unlike the sweeter High West variants I’ve sampled. A little bit of bitterness in the aftertaste. Probably my least favorite bottle of one of the most consistent labels out there. 3.7.
Good drink. Tough finish. I enjoyed it in South Carolina with Dwight Olson.
my favorite rye. a bit pricey but way better than the double rye so it's worth it. spicy, creamy, sweet, delicious.
This is good. Very bold flavors. Super nice rye
My favorite rye. It’s sweet, spicy, and delicious.
Excellent.  The most balanced rye I’ve had yet.   Mouthfeel is creamy and full, peppery but not hot.  This is a treat.
So much caramel spicy goodness. Favorite rye to date.
nice, round peppery rye.  anise, cinnamon and peppercorn with a touch of sweet molasses and pear.  marshmallow.  lots of marshmallow.
Very smooth, light vanilla, and crisp
not as good as double rye

Ominously, the recipe has changed significantly and is now "a blend of rye whiskeys ranging in age from 4 to 7 years." See here https://www.highwest.com/uploads/files/4910/HWDRendezvousRye.pdf and here
http://www.divingforpearlsblog.com/2019/05/constellation-brands-blows-up-high-west.html

Had multiple times. Neat. I have to agree with our professional assessor, which makes me feel sophisticated today, LOL
Nose : I do get the Mint and anise/Licorice for sure. Moderate ETOH. ( Wife got butter scotch after 20-45 min )
Palate: yes on the honey/molasses, minty fruit. No dark chocolate for me. Finish is long, hot and satisfying just as Rob describes !
A Home Bar faster mover for me, will blind taste with the buddies.
this rye is quite strong to the nose (alcohol and spice notes). adding water brings down the powerful notes of this whiskey, let's you enjoy it a bit more. it has a very good pleasant long finish
I was not impressed. I’ve had better experience with lower priced ryes.
Balanced. Rye takes a back seat to the sweetness. Almost like a bourbon. So smooth but not very complex. Overall, this was very enjoyable.
Very hot. Liked it with ice
Very good, but not that much better than double rye for twice the price
I like it. It’s got a nose of cereal and spice, but there’s a sweetness that also comes out along with the heat. I added a little water and actually found that it got spicier.
Really smooth. I like the rye flavor, but it’s a little heavy on the black licorice/anise flavor. But the fact it is so smooth makes the licorice flavor minor.
While I don't like rye whiskies, this one was better than all others I've tried. Pretty smooth for a rye.
Nice flavors, smooth, recommended.  Would buy it again, as well as interested in trying some of the other High West whiskeys.
Spice attack on the nose as well as on the palate and finish. Long, deeply satisfying!

Neat.  Nose is high rye (as expected) and leans towards the black licorice side.  It is incredibly oily on the glass.  Extremely smooth and pleasant mouth feel.  Buttery on the tongue initially, that’s interesting.  Dill initially but couldn’t find it later.  It’s really good.  Lots of vanilla, dessert like quality.  It’s something specific I can’t put my finger on it.  A spicy custard maybe?  Solid stuff.

Nose: hot, banana
Taste: mild, cinnamon, vanilla, banana, butterscotch
Finish: tannin, mild, high vanilla

This is really good rye.  There is a smoothness and dimension to this not found in most I have tried.  It is well above the HW Double Rye. IMO it has as much flavor as the WhistlePig 10 yr but more in line with flavors I prefer. (Cinnamon, cloves, and citrus).  The only reason it does not get 4 stars  from me is the $75 NC price.  I will just drink great bourbon and sip Sazerac 6 for a night cap every now and then when I need a change of pace.  I just can't see $75 much less $85 for WP 10yr.  Too many good bourbons out there to break bank on rye.   GSO Buyers Club selection. @ridethalightin

Batch 17K17

Delicious and immensely drinkable.  Rye spicy but not full of the black licorice taste that is so prevalent in ryes.  For me, the dill note comes and goes.  I like when it’s there and tend to miss it when it isn’t.  From my calendar computations, I believe this batch still includes both varieties of the Barton 16yo juice on hand at High West.  Wish HW would communicate exactly when the 16yo juice was replaced by in-house stock in RR the same way they did with Double Rye.  If I found another 2017 bottle I’d likely buy again.

I had this with a block of ice. I really enjoyed the flavor profile and how is changed as the ice melted into it. It was a bit spicy which was toned down by the ice. I think this flavor profile would make one heck of a good Old Fashioned

Really love the flavor notes: there's a bit of molasses , black licorice, and a hint of mint at the end. I usually don't like a dram that brings too much heat, but the heat for this rye rides the whole sip in a way that exited my taste buds instead of burning them alive. I can dig it.
Woodsy flavor, with a nice burn of respect.

Just FYI, Rendezvous Rye no longer has 19 year rye, as in the description. It has 4-7 year ryes now from MGP and HW. It’s a shell of its former self yet it still costs $80. High West pricing is stupid. Get the Double Rye which is still a good value.
Good rye spice on the nose that smooths into a slight oak that lingers on the palate. Balanced and not overly complex; straight forward rye whiskey.

Really well balanced rye. Nose is filled with dark dried cherries, spices and and dark chocolate. Taste follows with more rye spice, but its not overpowering and is balanced with more fruit notes and a long spicy finish.
A spicy rye with notes of vanilla, mint, and caramel. Packs quite a bite.

Spicy but still very smooth in the back end. 
Slight sweetness. Great sipper neat.
Dill and rye spice shine in this one.
Orange citrus and baking spice. Vanilla.  Subtly sweet and spicy. Nice

Lots of rye spice. I do get orange, cinnamon, and anise on the palate. The finish is moderate to long. If you like a spicy rye you will like this. It lacks the sweet front end I like in other ryes. It’s good. Not great.
I get so much dill from this one! I expect herbal spiciness from high west, but I struggled with this one.
Pleasant. Fruit and bright herbs, and anise. Long oily finish which is nice.
I smelled pine trees and enjoyed the buttery mouth

I'm not sure if I got the old or new recipe for this sample but this is a damn nice example of a rye whiskey. I would buy a bottle except that it sounds like it's yet another bourbon which they have devalued...it never seems to end in the sourced bourbon world. It's not really different from the taste profile of other bourbons but it does it very well. Perfect balance and beautifully crafted.

***ATTN. No longer aged up to 16yrs, but currently listed as 4 to 7 yrs on H.W. website!***
Dbl Rye in comparison is aged 2 to 7 yrs. What a letdown... I'm a fan of the HW Double Rye and at $40 it's a good value as well, so I was looking forward to trying this "better" bottle of rye from High West, still thinking it had older whiskey in it. This bottle has changed over the month I've had it open. After a week it tasted refined, mellow, lower heat with nice oak making just enough presence. I kept waiting for it to improve and wow me; but now after 3 to 4 weeks open (and 3/4 empty) it has taken on more heat and an over the top oak bitterness that wasn't there before that I do not enjoy - really went downhill. In summary I enjoy more exciting flavorful whiskeys than this - Pikesville is a great example at $10 less. I also enjoy the HW Double Rye more. This was refined and balanced for the first two weeks and an easy sipper (but underwhelming), so if this appeals to you just plan to finish your bottle before 3 weeks. Too much oxidation is Not kind to this one. I wont be getting another bottle.
With some ice this goes down easy, sweet taste can drink fast

Classic rye that has been tamed somewhat. It doesn't have the spiky quality I associate with rye. The spices, herbal flavors are there. I prefer double rye, as it's more aggressive, but this is a very friendly intro the the world of rye.

A terrific surprise. Nearly a perfect rye: a little spicy, a little sweet (none of the overwhelming, cloying sweetness of other ryes), and a little rye-dough semi-moldy/semi-poppyseed snap. A beautiful grab on the tongue -- like a little pinch of fire -- with no medicinal aftertaste, and just a little shadow of toffee in the aftertaste. Easy but with a little attitude, an extraordinary rye for the cost, and an ideal sipping Rye. Highly recommended.

Color: amber

Aroma: fig and rye abound, some clove

Taste: decent flavor on the front, mostly black pepper, rye, and cocoa. Hints of vanilla and cinnamon.

Finish: more like baking spices, but not sweet ones. Short finish with a bit of heat.

Batch 13J30

Found a 375ml bottle today of this older batch from 2013.

Nose: a lighter nose with dill, caramel, oak, rye spice
Palate: hits easy with classic Bourbon barrel notes initially, followed by a nice punch of rye spice, and with a fainter dill element than what’s on the nose. The flavors really pop, but are very coherent. Medium viscosity, and the heat level matches it’s proof.
Finish : medium finish similar to the palate flavors, but with the rye spice and light dill note reminding you that it is a Rye, not a Bourbon.

Overall, this is a quality Rye that is well balanced and just sips so damn easy I can’t stop refilling my glass. The downside for me is the state minimum price of $69.99 for a 750 ($37 for the 375)..... lots of stiff competition in that price range. Interestingly, the store had 750’s of the 2015 batch at $54.99, which scanned at $69.99. Of course, they wouldn’t honor the old sticker price (bastards). Oh well, I’ll just enjoy this ‘baby’ bottle and decide if I want to go back for the other 3 that were going unnoticed on the shelf.
Once I learned this is what Midwinters nights dream was made of I had to try it, wow this is incredible. I’d love to taste this side by side with midwinters night. My favorite rye to date !

The nose is strangely more of an emotion than a scent. Definitely rye, and you think it's light but it's not. It's elegant. The taste is very thick and oily. There's some nice spice at the end, but really it's a seamless, heavy, mystifying experience.

Nose: pleasant.  Caramel and vanilla 

Palate: very mild mild tasting rye.  Honestly, not a ton of flavor.  Light hints of vanilla and oak.  

Finish - a bit of a slow burn. Wood is dominant flavor.  Seems to initially finish quickly, but that is when this whiskey really begins to shine. Those earlier flavors that were barely noticeable, suddenly jump put at you.  

Overall - this whiskey was underwhelming at first and then BOOM - all the flavors hit you at once.  Really a surprising pour.
Maybe my favorite drink period. All of the complexity and spice of the Double Rye without the really young bite.

Pretty mild nose of dill, ginger, clove, citrus, rolled oats, and a tinge of ethanol.

Palate opens with butterscotch and honey transitioning to orange peel and a woodsy oak in the mid-palate, but then cuts right to the finish. Flavors aren’t particularly rich or punchy; they are just kind of “there”.

Spicy medium length finish features black pepper, cinnamon, anise, and dill with a kiss of mint. Mouthfeel is light and soft. 

A “sweet and spicy” rye that isn’t particularly herbal, this makes good showing with no real flaws, but also doesn’t knock my socks off. Which brings me to the price; at $58 this is overpriced for a “just fine” experience. High West Double Rye is a bolder, more herbal, and ultimately more interesting whiskey for about half the price. Misses the re-buy mark for me.
Sweet aroma, cinnamon notes, long lingering spicy finish. Very good
Missoula, MT helping Alex relocate his stuff East to UNY

1 cube, generous pour. 
Nose: good balance of rawest grape or apricot fruit, some chocolate, wheat / honey nut cheerios. Not much spice (see proof), not much oak, not extremely complex or bold. Not really getting the mint others are. 
Palate: short to moderate finish. Pretty smooth, with hint of red hot candy spice while it lasts. Sweet throughout though.
The longer I go without having a full bottle of this the more I want some

I hated this at first. It tasted like pickles and lemon...but after a week it’s really grown on me! I’m a big fan of their double rye and tend to like sweeter whiskey. Regardless, this one grows on you in all it’s sour glory.
Rich flavors of molasses, bit of cinnamon and fruity with spicy long finish

2014 bottle. Dill, rye spice, vanilla. Some nice complexity from the 16 year old Barton's rye in this pre-2018 batch. Really well balanced. Oily on the glass. Long finish that lingers. If you can find a bottle prior to 2017 with the old formula for $65 or so, buy it. You won't be disappointed.
Beautiful light spice values. Caramelized butter flavors. The butter carries over into the nose.  This one is a tongue coating whiskey, filling the whole palate and finishing with a subtle sweetness.
Slightly less spicy and a bit sweeter than HW’s double rye, but incredibly smooth and balanced. It’s nearly double the price point so something I’d prefer to sip than mix.

Just opened up my bottle that’s from a 2017 batch. It’s got a rather boring nose, not a whole lot going on. The palate was super spicy but not very much rye flavor.
The rye is definitely there but it’s not as pronounced as I was expecting. I’ve always loved their double rye so I had high hopes for this one. As of now, I think I prefer the double rye which isn’t a huge problem I guess because it’s cheaper anyway. I’ll give it a few weeks to open up and see if anything changes. By no means bad but I had higher expectations.
Another high west with off putting mint on the nose, but the tastes make up for it somewhat, very spicy and complex

This is one of my go to whiskeys anymore. It has mint on the nose. Nice and spicy on the taste and hot at the end that last a while. Very smooth one of the best rye’s you need to try if you haven’t. Highly recommend!!
Liked neat.  Better after ice melted.
Sweet aroma, spicy, sweet notes. Longer spicy finish. Will revisit
